awd_titl_txt: Travel: Student Travel Grant for 2023 Computational Geometry Week
awd_abstract_narration:
Computational geometry is an important area of computer science, with applications in graphics, 3D modeling, robotics and topology. Geometry Week organizes the flagship conference for computational geometry with several workshops, most notably the Young Researchers' Forum, where PhD students and Postdoctoral researchers can present their work. The project expects to support the equivalent of 10 full support participants and 5 half support participants. The proposal also aims to increase the representation of under-represented groups at the meeting.

The travel support provided in this project will help bring young researchers in the field of computational geometry together and create synergies and idea exchanges to solve problems and open up new areas for study. Past versions of this effort have been productive in generating several high-impact research papers in addition to encouraging and mentoring young researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

por.por_cntn:
Computational geometry is the algorithmic study of problems involving geometric data. Research in the field addresses fundamental questions that arise from diverse application domains, including robotics, data science, networks, sensing, biology, computer vision, geometric modeling, manufacturing, and many other areas of science and engineering.

This project provided travel support for 28 students to attend Computational Geometry Week 2023, hosted on the main campus of the University of Texas at Dallas. CG Week is the premier international research event in Computational Geometry, and includes the Symposium on Computational Geometry, the oldest and most influential conference in Computational Geometry. CG Week also includes various workshops, the media exposition, the CG:SHOP geometric optimization challenge, and the Young Researchers Forum, which is a venue designed for students and recent graduates to present their research to the broader community.

By funding 28 students to attend CG Week, this project has broadened the participation of students in the Computational Geometry research community. The supported students attended, participated, and in many cases gave talks at CG Week, allowing them to solidify existing contacts and make new research contacts for ongoing collaborations. Testimonials submitted by the supported show that they were deeply engaged in the research events, and that attending CG Week benefited them both in their research and their career development.


Last Modified: 07/20/2024
Modified by: Benjamin Raichel
